text: How the hunt for this deadly virus shaped the search for coronavirus’s origins @karinbrulliard @bbguari  https://t.co/frLGlXzGZ0

CureVac's first mRNA coronavirus vaccine was a huge disappointment. Now, they're using *modified RNA* on their do-over. Shows the importance of basic science. Here's Drew Weissman, literally pointing to a sculpture of the "modification" in modified RNA
https://t.co/5Kov4MQohg
RT @britsham: Paige Ruiz believed in the coronavirus vaccine and planned to get it -- just as soon as her baby was born. She never got the…

Moderna, under intense pressure from the Biden administration and advocates to send more of its coronavirus vaccine to lower-income countries, announced it would built a plant in Africa -- a multi-year project that will not address the urgent need https://t.co/n30nJEcvze

⬇️Geoff and Olubukola Abiona made the coronavirus spike protein (the key to the vaccine),  @CynthiaZiwawo  focused on antibody assays. 

Training in science is like an apprenticeship - and they helped save the world as their first jobs out of college. This was their warm up. https://t.co/dApigNmz2y

We're all just catching up to Weissman and Kariko. But they're moving on. Weissman wants to cure sickle cell anemia, create a universal flu vaccine, end HIV. His interest in covid-19 is in creating a pan-coronavirus vaccine to prevent the next pandemic.

One thing that becomes super clear talking to @WeissmanLab is a polite impatience.

He keeps getting asked about stuff that happened 15, 20 years ago. But covid-19 was the beginning, not the end of the medical potential. 
https://t.co/UTmPSKr7PD

Graham's idea is that we shouldn't have to depend on luck. We should solve the 2 dozenish other viruses that might spawn a pandemic and have similar solutions for vaccines sitting on the shelf. Plug and play.

Although this pandemic has been devastating, we were actually really ready for it. We were... lucky.
-They had figured out how to optimize a vaccine years earlier
-There was a team of scientists working on coronaviruses, way before it was recognized as a cool area of science

When the pandemic started, Graham @McLellan_Lab  and @KizzyPhD hit the ground running. But Graham also wanted to make sure that we appreciated a group of 3 intrepid young scientists, just starting their careers @GeoffreyHutch11  @CynthiaZiwawo and Olu Abiona

He talked a lot about @McLellan_Lab and RSV, a childhood respiratory disease. What did that have to do with covid-19? The work they did to figure out how to make a better RSV vaccine paved the way for the covid-19 vaccines.

But he was so generous with his limited time, so engrossed in science - and also talked so much about what other people were contributing. It was honestly a little hard to discern how original his ideas were - and how eerily spot on they had prepared us to battle this pandemic.

Covering vaccines for almost 2 years, I've met some incredible scientists. They are the vaccine vanguard, the people who prepared us to fight this pandemic. They were not famous before this. They are *incredible and really inspiring humans.*  

https://t.co/QZahokrSn5
